text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: James Clark
Address: 208 Yeadall, James Clark
Birthplace: Carp Village, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? N.W.M.S., S.A., S.O., S.O., S.O.
Where had you been living before that? Near Ottawa, Ont. & Brownsville, Ont.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Usually, 4
How far was it to your nearest store? Strathroy, 10 Miles, Later, 5 Miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every several months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, Rats, Sugar, Salt, Dried fruit, Butter, Lard, Syrup, Baking Soda, Cream of Tartar, Baking Powder, Yeast — Coal oil and not an over supply of any of them.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? No. 1, Graham
In what quantities did you buy it? At first, 10 lbs. per batch, 5 lbs. at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3
How much did you use graham flour? Not at all
Whole wheat flour? Not at all
Was flour milled locally? Yes, How far away? 3 miles What year? 1906 and after
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $2
What other grain products did you use? ..............................................
Cornmeal? Yes Whole Wheat? No Farina? No
Other? ...............................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By hand doing custom work with ordinary grinder
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office
Box 8700 Station Main
Regina, Sask., S4P 3A2

Name: James Clark
Address: 120, Tyndall Ave.
Volkoma, Sask.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ________

Where did you set up housekeeping? ________

Where had you been living before that? ________

For how many people did you prepare meals? ________

How far was it to your nearest store? ________

How often could a visit be made to the store? ________

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ________

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ________

In what quantities did you buy it? ________

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ________

How much did you use graham flour? ________

Was flour milled locally? ________

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ________

What other grain products did you use? ________

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ________

How did you grind it? ________
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10-lb. bags.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Rogers.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10-oz.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? A cow.

Butter? Around 25¢ per lb.

Eggs? Keeps a few hens.

What was the price of butter? Of eggs? 6¢ doz.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Mostly raised a hog.

How did you get fresh meat? From local butcher. Also bought quarters of beef.

How often did you get fresh meat? Seldom.

How did you preserve meat? Dry salted.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Some.

What kinds? Wild fowl.

For how long? 10 years or thereabouts.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Very little.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh & canned.

Kinds? Salmon, Pike, Rockwell and Rock.
Tyndall, James Clark
Box 125,
Mokotin, Sask.

1906

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS
In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lb. 4 lbs.
What was the price for a ten pound sack or white sugar?
What brand or golden corn syrup did you use? Royalite.
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.
At what prices?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS
How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.
What was the price of butter? $1.00.
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.
Did you make butter? Yes.
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH
What was your meat supply in the early years? Farm raised.
How did you get fresh meat? Farm raised.
How often did you get fresh meat? Weekly.
How did you preserve meat? Salted.
Was there a "beer ring" in your neighborhood? No.
If so what year was it organized?
Did you use game?
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet? Very little.
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned?
Kinds?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? At what price?

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)

Price? What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store?

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1907 Cabbage 1929 Carrots 1909 Onions 1909

Turnips 1948 Beets 1928

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)?

What weight? How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?

What was the price of prunes?

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples; pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying?

peas? corn? beans? Saskatoons? other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning?

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

What year did you first preserve meat by canning?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? (A) (B) (C) (D)

At what price? ________

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ________

Price? ________

What other beverages were used? ________

What was the price of prunes? ________

peas ________

corn ________

beans ________

other foods ________

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal Yeast Cake
Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes
Using starter? No
Using hops? No
Salt rising? No
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Baking soda? Yes
Cream of tartar? Yes
Did you make your own baking powder? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) **Well** ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? **3.5 miles** ........................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) **Pail, barrel** ....

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

At first we dug wells but found no adequate supply. Later about 1918 we began drilling wells and found water anywhere from 55 to 200 feet. My own well is 96 feet with plenty of water.

### 12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, stream, dugout) **Well**

How far was this water from your house? **In a formula**

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

At first we dug wells but found no adequate supply.

Started about 1918 we began drilling wells and found water anywhere from 55 to 20 feet. My own well is 96 feet with plenty of water.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? 
If you made your own, did you use lye? wood ashes?
What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? 
Where did you get your fuel? 
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Around 1914-15 when we began raising layer crops we bought coal for heating. During later years we used coal in winter and coal oil in summer for cooking purposes and heating oil for whenever we needed extra heat. Probably since 1949.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) 
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) 
By whom was your first cook stove made? 
What year was it purchased? Price? 
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) 
For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) 
When did you first see enamel ware? 
Aluminum?
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Where did you get your fuel?

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, listing dates where possible.

Answered 1914-15 when we had only logs for our stove. We used coal for heating. During later years we used coal, wood, and oil in summer for cooking purposes and heating oil for whenever you needed extra heat.

Partially since 1949.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? What year was it purchased?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

1906 - Food purchased was mostly in bulk and wrapped in ordinary paper sacks (except canned foods) while now there is mostly cartons which add little or anything to the goodness of the product and increase the price.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

July 1906 -

Breakfast - Oatmeal Porridge - Condensed milk,
Buttered toast,
Coffee,

Dinner - Potatoes + pork,
Hot water - bread.

Supper - Fried potatoes - pork,
Bread butter, jam or stewed fruit,
Hot water.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1908.

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

N.B. We were mostly all bachelors in the district so there was nothing elaborate only I remember we had a good time.
We had Turkey, potatoes, bread and some sort of dessert.
Primarily I remember the friendship which has continued through the years.

Present - Hugh Corryan - 31 yrs.
Fidelia Belliveau - 31 yrs.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No.
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS
Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received
with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest
year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family
with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or
summer.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1908.
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

N.B. Mr. was mostly all bachelor... the district is so close we
wouldn't eat out only Remember we had a hard time.
Pineapple, turkey, potato, bread and some kind of dessert.
Brought by the guests.

Povesh - Hynd Canyon - 31 yrs.
Edith Belliveau - 31 yrs.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally
produced foods? Give details.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There is essentially no difference in the preparation of meals except there is a little more variety and storage such as locker plants furnish fresh products at all times and home canning also helps.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Food has never been a major problem and with the exception of buying instead of baking bread there is little difference in the menu.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There is essentially no difference in the preparation of meals except that there is a little more variety and always such as Locker plants furnish fresh products at all times and homes owning also help.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Food has never been a major problem and with the exception of buying canned food there is little difference in the manner.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
